text:
*[Bug 18949] New: When neither %R_USER% nor %HOME% is set, path.expand('~') may return ANSI instead of UTF-8*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18949>

            Bug ID: 18949
           Summary: When neither %R_USER% nor %HOME% is set,
                    path.expand('~') may return ANSI instead of UTF-8
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.5.x
          Hardware: All
                OS: Windows 64-bit
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Startup
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:ikrylov@disroot.org|ikrylov@disroot.org>

Created attachment 3549
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3549&action=edit>
Suggested fix

Previously reported by OneDrive users (e.g.
[1](<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-help/2024-March/479033.html>)), but not
limited to OneDrive (e.g.
[2](<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-help/2025-September/481246.html>)). In
order to reproduce the bug, a non-ASCII home directory path is needed, together
with `%HOME%` being unset (it is set by default in the Rtools terminal).

```
$ gdb --args /c/R-svn/bin/x64/Rscript.exe -e 'path.expand("~")'
(gdb) unset environment HOME
(gdb) b getRUser
```

Since the environment variables are unset, the first branch is not taken, but
the second one is:

```
63          if ((p = getenv("R_USER")) || (p = getenv("HOME"))) {
64              RUser = (char *)malloc(strlen(p) + 1);
65              if (RUser)
66                  strcpy(RUser, p);
67          } else if ((RUser = ShellGetPersonalDirectory())) {
```

```
(gdb) until 67
ShellGetPersonalDirectory () at shext.c:34
34          if (SHGetKnownFolderPath(&FOLDERID_Documents, KF_FLAG_CREATE, NULL,
```

The return value from `SHGetKnownFolderPath` is correct, but then it's
converted to ANSI:

```
41                      wcstombs(result, wpath, needed + 1);
(gdb) n
(gdb) p wpath
$1 = 0x4420690 L"C:\\Users\\Felhaszn\xc3\xa1l\xc3\xb3\\Documents"
(gdb) p result
$2 = 0x441e1d0 "C:\\Users\\Felhaszn\341l\363\\Documents"
```

I think that `wcstombs` is not converting to UTF-8 because the locale has not
yet been initialised at this point:

```
(gdb) p (char*)setlocale(0,0)
$4 = 0x4418144 "C"
```

`WideCharToMultiByte` seems to do the right thing without requiring the locale
to be initialised. Home I'm not missing anything else.

text:
*[Bug 18950] New: CMake recipe GdalConfig is faulty*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18950>

            Bug ID: 18950
           Summary: CMake recipe GdalConfig is faulty
           Product: Rtools
           Version: 4.5
          Hardware: All
                OS: Windows 64-bit
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Toolchain and libraries
          Assignee: <mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>
          Reporter: <mailto:caiohamamura@gmail.com|caiohamamura@gmail.com>

I am trying to create a CMake project dependent on GDAL. But it turns out that
the `GDALConfig.cmake` is not working, because there are some msys2 relative
paths. Some of them are wrong even if the relative path was resolved.

```
[ 50%] Building C object CMakeFiles/simple_gdal.dir/main.c.obj
make[2]: *** No rule to process the target
'/usr/lib/mxe/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-w64-mingw32.static.posix/14.2.0/libgomp.a',
which is needed by 'simple_gdal.exe'.  Stop.
make[1]: *** [CMakeFiles/Makefile2:83: CMakeFiles/simple_gdal.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [Makefile:136: all] Error 2
```

Here `libgomp.a` is not being found, because even if it were to use the
relative path it should be:

```
/usr/lib/mxe/usr/x86_64-w64-mingw32.static.posix/lib/gcc/x86_64-w64-mingw32.static.posix/14.2.0/libgomp.a
```

Not:

```
/usr/lib/mxe/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-w64-mingw32.static.posix/14.2.0/libgomp.a
```

I can confirm that the path is hardcoded in line 73 of GDAL-targets.cmake. But
even if I fix that, the Rtools environment won't let me use the relative path. 

Using the absolute path works, but then another problem arises with
`hdf5_hl.a`:

```
C:\rtools45\x86_64-w64-mingw32.static.posix\bin/ld.exe: cannot find
/usr/lib/mxe/usr/x86_64-w64-mingw32.static.posix/lib/libhdf5_hl.a: No such file
or directory
```

It is using the relative path here. I couldn't find the way to fix that though.
But if I fix the `@CMakeFiles/simple_gdal.dir/linkLibs.rsp` manually to use the
absolute path it compiles successfully.


# Steps to reproduce

### main.c
```
#include "gdal.h"
#include <stdio.h>

int main() {
    GDALAllRegister();  // just call something from GDAL
    printf("GDAL test program compiled and linked successfully.\n");
    return 0;
}
```

### CMakeLists.txt
```
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.24)
project(simple_gdal C CXX)

find_package(GDAL CONFIG REQUIRED)

add_executable(simple_gdal main.c)

target_link_libraries(simple_gdal PRIVATE GDAL::GDAL)
```

### Bash commands
```
cmake -B build && cmake --build build -v
```

# PS

If I use the msys2 provided gdal I can compile with no problem:

```
pacman -S ucrt64/mingw-w64-ucrt-x86_64-gdal
rm -rf build;cmake -B build -DCMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=/ucrt64 && cmake --build build
-v
```

Its actually even better, because the configure phase will be a lot faster.

# Steps to reproduce

pacman -S ucrt64/mingw-w64-ucrt-x86_64-gdal

-v
Its actually even better, because the configure phase will be a lot faster.

text:
*[Bug 18950] CMake recipe GdalConfig is faulty*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18950>

--- Comment #1 from Caio Hamamura (<mailto:caiohamamura@gmail.com|caiohamamura@gmail.com>) ---
I forgot to mention that if I use `pkg-config` it does work successfully:

```
find_package(PkgConfig REQUIRED)
pkg_check_modules(GDAL IMPORTED_TARGET gdal)

add_executable(simple_gdal main.c)

target_link_libraries(simple_gdal PRIVATE PkgConfig::GDAL)
```

But since the `find_package(<pkgname> CONFIG)` is the standard modern CMake way
to link to libraries (and that in many other environments the faulty one will
be `pkg-config`) it would be better if we could fix that one since it does not
seem to be hard, since the default packages provided by MSYS2, I also tried
`vcpkg` and it only works with `find_package(GDAL CONFIG)` it will fail with
`pkg_check_modules`.
